comments.content: The font is [Le Asterix](http://web.archive.org/web/20070816151241/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/le-asterix/). It has all upper case letters but the ones from the shifted keys have a different shape, given a more realistic simulation of real printing. This has a bold version called Le Obelisk, which I didn't see at MyFonts

[Here it is](http://web.archive.org/web/20070816151241/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/le-obelix/). You just had the spelling wrong. These are from the famous-everywhere-but-the-U.S. French comic strip [Asterix](http://web.archive.org/web/20070816151241/http:/www.asterix.tm.fr/france/actualites/asterisque2/pro_jou3.htm).
Ah, yes, Obelix! Now I recall the spelling similarity in the two names. I think I have them both in my Guide, I just got too lazy to look for it.

[Asterix and Obelix](http://web.archive.org/web/20070816151241/http:/www.asterix.tm.fr/) are classics. The original French   
editions are hilarious, and it's incredible how the   
authors do magic with language: countless delightful   
word plays on every single page. And the references   
to modern day history and numerous cameos by famous   
personalities are gold. The comic books are even used   
in school to teach French!

I got a couple of the French editions as gifts in the late sixties when I was learning French in school. They were given to me by a collegue of my dad's from Denmark who stayed with us a few times when he was in the U.S. on business. I still have them, though they are very tattered now. A few years ago I started buying more of them (a few in French, mostly in English) to read to my daughter. We both love them. Astérix Légionnaire, the first one I ever saw, is still my favorite.
In Légionnaire, it cracks me up that the guy from Belgium has Tintin's hair.

My mother collected the complete series. She bound   
them into handy hardcover volumes of five or six   
albums each. The great thing is you can read them   
on so many levels: for kids it's very funny slapstick   
and situation humour, but as you grow older and   
reread them you start noticing the subtle word plays,   
the celebrity cameos, the references to history,   
politics, social issues, cultural preconceptions...   
they're just great.

As Charlie Brown would say: AAUGHH! The stuff in the word balloons in Asterix comics is LETTERING not FONTS or TYPOGRAPHY. \*sigh\* (One of my pet peeves is the way people refer to any kind of letter style as a “font,” regardless of whether it is actually a font or not.)

I do enjoy the way they use different lettering styles in Asterix to indicate what language is being spoken. Clever.
